Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Banana\Banana (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes:
Time & Fun Banana was an LCD handheld game released in 1981 as a part of the Time & Fun series of games.
The gameplay is similar to Nintendo's Manhole Game & Watch where you have to keep pedestrians from slipping on the banana peel on the streets. With each miss an ambulance appears in the corner, and if you get five then the game is over. Game A is easier than Game B with the Time mode automatically switching on when left alone for 30 seconds.
Game.Title: Banana

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Bomb Fight\Bomb Fight (VTech, Mini Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Bomb Fight is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1982.
Game.Title: Bomb Fight

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Frog Boaster [1992]\Frog Boaster (Elektronika).mgw
Game.Notes: Frog Boaster is a portable electronic game released by "Elektronika" in 1992. This sample was produced in the USSR. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Frog Boaster

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Hippo Teeth (Vtech, Mini) [1982]\Hippo Teeth (VTech, Mini Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Hippo Teeth is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1982. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Hippo Teeth (Vtech, Mini)

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Donkey Kong Jr. (Coleco) [1983]\Donkey Kong Jr. (Coleco).mgw
Game.Title: Donkey Kong Jr. (Coleco)

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Mario_s Bombs Away [1983]\Mario's Bombs Away (Nintendo, Panorama Screen).mgw
Game.Notes:
Mario's Bombs Away is a Game & Watch game released as a part of the Panorama series on November 13, 1983. It is a single-screen single-player Game & Watch. It features an unlit color LCD screen that faces downward in order to expose the translucent rear to an external light source, such as daylight. Hirokazu Tanaka composed the game music.
The player character is a military-clad Mario who delivers bombs from left to right, and must keep them away from flaming oil spills and enemy torches. Action is viewed in a mirror that reflects the screen.
Game.Title: Mario's Bombs Away

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Escape [1981]\Escape (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Escape is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1984. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Escape

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Donkey Kong [1982]\Donkey Kong (Coleco).mgw
Game.Notes: Donkey Kong is a Game & Watch game released as a part of the Multi Screen series on June 3, 1982. It is a dual-screen single-player Game & Watch with an orange body. It opens like a compact, with an upper and lower screen. This game was also the first Game & Watch to feature a directional pad.
Game.Title: Donkey Kong

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Engine Room [1984]\Engine Room (VTech, Explorer Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Engine Room is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1984. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Engine Room

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Penguin Land [1983]\Penguin Land (Bandai, LSI Game Double Play).mgw
Game.Notes:
A very entertaining game with (again) a penguin against a seal. Avoid the bombs hitting the ground. Best way is to throw them to the other side of the iceberg, to the seal! Meanwhile you have to put 3 ice blocks together, to reach and eat the fish ...
Sophisticated game for 2 players. There are 6 more games from this Double Play type.
Game.Title: Penguin Land

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Donkey Kong II [1983]\Donkey Kong II (Nintendo, Multi Screen).mgw
Game.Notes: Donkey Kong II is a Game & Watch game released as a part of the Multi Screen series on March 7, 1983. It is a dual-screen single-player Game & Watch with a brown body. It opens like a compact, with an upper and lower screen. Hirokazu Tanaka composed the game music.
Game.Title: Donkey Kong II

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Tron [1981]\Tron (Tomytronic).mgw
Game.Notes: TRON is a handheld game released by Tomy in 1982. It consists of three games that are based on action sequences from the movie TRON. In the first game, the player must move his light cycle around the Game Grid to cut off three Warrior Elite light cycles one at a time. In the second game, Tron and Sark throw discs at each other in the hope that either of them will miss catching it, causing that player to lose one of his four bars, the game being a combination of the jai-alai ring game from the movie and the arcade game Pong. In the third game, the player must throw his disc into the heart of the MCP to destroy it once and for all. Once all three games have been completed, the cycle starts anew with a faster and higher level of difficulty.
Game.Title: Tron

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Pancake [1981]\Pancake (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Pancake is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1981. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Pancake

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Grab Man [1988]\Grab Man (unknown manufacturer, Game & Time).mgw
Game.Notes: Very nice Pac Man clone. Foreign version by Biktoys (unknown).
Game.Title: Grab Man

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Armor Battle\Armor Battle (Mattel Electronics).mgw
Game.Notes:
• Real battle competition
• The skill of real play
• The latest micro-electronics
ARMOR BATTLE
You are on a dangerous tank mission. To reach and destroy your assigned target, you must maneuver through a field filled with enemy mines. Although these are hidden, the mine detection equipment in your tank warns you of their presence by producing a buzzing sound. This is your signal to change course on route to your target. If you should stumble into a mine, your tank will be "destroyed" and returned to its original starting position. If you get through the minefield and successfully engage the target, the built-in computer will automatically set up another challenge with a new starting position, target location, and minefield.
Game.Title: Armor Battle

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Galaxy II [1981]\Galaxy II (Epoch).mgw
Game.Notes:
Galaxy II / Astro Wars was a shoot 'em up, with play involving four phases of dodging enemy missiles and firing back at the squadrons of alien command ships, warships and attacking fighters as well as a docking challenge for additional bonus points.
Astro Wars (specifically) was made in Great Britain in 1981 by Grandstand under licence from Epoch Co., who sold the game in Japan under the title Super Galaxian (スーパーギャラクシアン). There were two versions of Astro Wars - an earlier version had the Astro Wars motif printed in red and a later version printed in white.
Game.Title: Galaxy II

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Defendo [1984]\Defendo (VTech, Explorer Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: A Schiacciapensieri Polistil release for Italy. Survival-tool type with a built-in flashlight and compass.
Game.Title: Defendo

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Monkey [1981]\Monkey (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: MONKEY Vintage Electronic Retro Hand Held Handheld Game.
Game.Title: Monkey

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Crazy Chewy [1982]\Crazy Chewy (VTech, Electronic Tini-Arcade).mgw
Game.Notes: Crazy Chewy is an electronic tabletop game released by VTech in 1982. In Japan, this game was released under the name Astro Wars. This game is similar to Namco's popular Pac-Man arcade game at the time.
Game.Title: Crazy Chewy

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Donkey Angler [1983]\Donkey Angler (Gakken, LCD Card Game).mgw
Game.Notes: This game was released outside Japan as Fishing Boy.
Game.Title: Donkey Angler

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Explorers of Space [1989]\Explorers of Space (Elektronika).mgw
Game.Notes: Explorers of Space is a portable electronic game released by Elektronika under the brand in 1989. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Explorers of Space

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Safari [1981]\Safari (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Safari is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1981. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Safari

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Sleep Walker [1981]\Sleep Walker (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Another game from the Time & Fun series. This is the French release by Ludotronic.
Game.Title: Sleep Walker

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Chicky Woggy [1982]\Chicky Woggy (VTech, Arcade Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: This is the Italian release by Polistil. Also released as tabletop version.
Game.Title: Chicky Woggy

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Turtle Bridge [1982]\Turtle Bridge (Nintendo, Wide Screen).mgw
Game.Notes:
The player receives items and must cross a bridge of five turtles to deliver the items to the receiver on the other side of a lake. Each time the player delivers an item, they earn three points. On the way back to the home bank to grab the next item, the player earns from two to 12 extra points depending on how fast they return. However, the turtles at times will go down into the lake to eat fish, and if the player jumps onto or stays on a descending turtle, that player will fall into the lake and lose a life. Also, the player might need to wait for the receiver to appear and cannot return to the home bank while carrying an item. If the player reaches 200 or 500 points without any misses, then no fish will appear for the turtles for 20 to 40 seconds. If the player has any misses at either score, every miss will be cleared instead. The player receives a Game Over when they lose three lives.
In Game A, most fish appear to the left and right of the center turtle, and it does not descend unless the player stays on it too long. In Game B, however, fish will appear more frequently for the center turtle.
Game.Title: Turtle Bridge

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Dungeons & Dragons Computer Fantasy Game [1981]\Dungeons & Dragons Computer Fantasy Game (Mattel Electronics, Arcade Action Series).mgw
Game.Notes: A fun little adventure in the dungeon! Find the magic arrow, avoid the traps and get that dragon!
Game.Title: Dungeons & Dragons Computer Fantasy Game

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Snoopy (Panorama Screen) [1983]\Snoopy (Nintendo, Panorama Screen).mgw
Game.Notes: Snoopy is a Game & Watch game released as a part of the Table Top series on June 5, 1983, and as a part of the Panorama series on August 30, 1983. It was the first game in the Panorama series. It is a single-screen single-player Game & Watch. Hirokazu Tanaka composed the game music.
Game.Title: Snoopy (Panorama Screen)

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Tennis Menace [1982]\Tennis Menace (VTech, Sporty Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Tiny necklace type of game, with built-in stopwatch. This is a foreign Ludotronic release: Colere au Tennis.
Game.Title: Tennis Menace

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Fowling [1989]\Fowling (Elektronika).mgw
Game.Notes: Fowling is a portable electronic game released by "Elektronika" in 1989. This sample was produced in the USSR. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Fowling

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Condor [1981]\Condor (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Another game from the Time & Fun series. This is the French release by Ludotronic.
Game.Title: Condor

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Hot Line [1981]\Hot Line (VTech, Mini Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Rare blister pack version for Italy by POLISTIL: La Linea Rossa
Game.Title: Hot Line

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Isidoro & Sonja_ Caccia al Ladro [1982]\Caccia al Ladro (VTech, Mini Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Title: Isidoro & Sonja: Caccia al Ladro

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Towering Rescue [1981]\Towering Rescue (Gakken, LCD Card Game).mgw
Game.Notes: 1981 Gakken TOWERING RESCUE Vintage LCD Electronic Handheld Video Game and Watch.
Game.Title: Towering Rescue

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Monkey Jump [1982]\Monkey Jump (VTech, Arcade Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Arcade Time & Fun series, basically a Donkey Kong clone, also released by Innovator Electronics as Kid Kong. This is also available as a tabletop game called Wild Man Jump by Vtech (and I've also seen the tabletop released by Cheryco as Monkey Jump and Ludotronic as Hop' Man (in France)).
Game.Title: Monkey Jump

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Snoopy Tennis [1982]\Snoopy Tennis (Nintendo, Wide Screen).mgw
Game.Notes: Snoopy Tennis is a Game & Watch video game released in 1982 by Nintendo. The game was very successful, perhaps due to the Snoopy label, with Nintendo producing an estimated 1,200,000 worldwide. In the game, you control Snoopy, moving him up and down to make him hit the oncoming tennis balls with your racket. It was released on the Wide Screen format. A version of the game was released as a keychain title under the miniclassics label. The control button leaflet, which was only present in this game's box and Fire Attack's, showcases various characters from the Peanuts franchise. Unsurprisingly, due to licensing issues, the game was not released in any of the Game & Watch video games, though it was mentioned in Super Smash Bros. Brawl for the Wii.
Game.Title: Snoopy Tennis

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Las Vegas [1981]\Las Vegas (Bandai, LCD Game Digital).mgw
Game.Notes: Las Vegas: 9 games were made in this colorful series. It was also released in Europe in a different box and a blister version.
Game.Title: Las Vegas

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Motor Cross [1983]\Motor Cross (Queentex).mgw
Game.Notes: Vintage 1983 Handheld Digital Daredevil Moto Cross Electronic Game by Tomy.
Game.Title: Motor Cross

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Head to Head_ Electronic Baseball [1982]\Baseball (VTech, Explorer Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Title: Head to Head: Electronic Baseball

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Pirate [1981]\Pirate (VTech, Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Pirate is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1981. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Pirate

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Mario Bros. [1983]\Mario Bros. (Nintendo, Multi Screen).mgw
Game.Notes:
Mario Bros. is a Game & Watch game released as a part of the Multi Screen series on March 14, 1983. It is a dual-screen single-player Game & Watch with a maroon body. It opens like a Japanese book (to the right), with a left and right screen.
Mario and Luigi are working in a bottling plant, on either side of several stacked conveyor belts. The object of the game is to move boxes of bottles through the machine without dropping any. Each brother can climb a ladder to one of three positions. Mario receives a box at the bottom right, and must be in his lowest position to move it into the bottling machine. The box moves left through the machine, to Luigi, who must be in his lowest position to move it to the next level, which moves it to the right, to Mario's middle position, who raises it to the next level. The box moves to Luigi's middle position, then to Mario's highest position, and finally to Luigi's highest position, where Luigi throws the box onto a truck. When the truck is full, the Brothers have a short break, before getting back to work. Successfully moving a box up one level earns the player 1 point, and loading the truck with eight boxes earns 10 points, for a total of 58 points for all the boxes in the truck. However, if a Brother isn't there to catch a box, it falls to the floor and breaks, angering the Brothers' supervisor, resulting in a miss. The third miss ends the game.
Game.Title: Mario Bros.

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Egg [1981]\Egg (Nintendo, Wide Screen).mgw
Game.Notes: Zeke Wolf must catch chicken eggs sliding down a conveyor belt. Each egg gives the player one point, and if the player can get 200 and 500 points, all misses are erased. As the game progresses, the eggs will slide down faster. To play, the player has to use the Control Pad to move.
Game.Title: Egg

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Tom & Jerry Popper [1983]\Tom & Jerry Popper (Gakken, LCD Card Game).mgw
Game.Notes: Tom & Jerry Popper: a handheld electronic game from 1983.
Game.Title: Tom & Jerry Popper

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Lifeboat [1983]\Lifeboat (Nintendo, Multi Screen).mgw
Game.Notes: A fire breaks out on a luxury passenger liner, forcing the passengers to abandon ship. The player needs to place a lifeboat below them to rescue them. However, only four passengers can fit into the lifeboat, so rescuers must pull it towards the shore on either side to offload the passengers. The player receives a point for every passenger who enters the lifeboat and for every passenger delivered safely to shore. As time passes, the passengers will move faster. If a passenger misses the lifeboat or the player tries to catch one in a full lifeboat, the passenger will fall into the water and get eaten by a shark, and the player will receive a miss. If this happens at the same time a passenger is being unloaded to shore, the player will not receive any points. If the player reaches 300 points without any misses, the points will be worth double until the player does get a miss. If the player has any misses at said score, every miss will be cleared instead. When the player gets three misses, they receive a Game Over. Game A features two lifeboats (one on each side), while Game B features one (which can go to either side).
Game.Title: Lifeboat

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Sub Chase [1978]\Sub Chase (Mattel Electronics).mgw
Game.Notes: Sub Chase is a portable electronic game released by Mattel Electronics brand in 1978. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Sub Chase

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Isodoro & Sonja_ Cessate il Fuoco [1982]\Cessate il Fuoco (VTech, Mini Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes:
This is a italian only release by Polistil: Cessate Il Fuoco. Based on comic stories of Heathcliff (called Isodoro in Italy).
Another game with Isodoro & Sonja is Caccia al Ladro.
Game.Title: Isidoro & Sonja: Cessate il Fuoco

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Wild Man Jump [1981]\Wild Man Jump (VTech, Electronic Tini-Arcade).mgw
Game.Notes: Wild Man Jump by Vtech 1981 Rare Tabletop game, in which you play a Donkey Kong type game. This game features a large multi-coloured display using backlit LCD technology.
Game.Title: Wild Man Jump

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Donkey Kong Circus [1984]\Donkey Kong Circus (Nintendo, Panorama Screen).mgw
Game.Notes:
One of the few Game & Watch units to feature full color, Donkey Kong Circus is a remake of the second Mickey Mouse Game & Watch game, which was released worldwide seven months earlier
Donkey Kong balances on a barrel while juggling pineapples and avoiding the flaming torches. Mario watches his performance. If Donkey Kong loses a pineapple, Mario would laugh at him. If Donkey Kong manages to grasp a fireball, he will flail.
Game.Title: Donkey Kong Circus

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Pac Man [1981]\Pac Man (Tomytronic).mgw
Game.Notes: Pac Man: Electronic handheld games, also referred to as handheld LCD games, are dedicated handheld game systems with built-in games. Many Pac-Man handhelds of this variety have been released, starting as early as 1981.
Game.Title: Pac Man

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Mickey Mouse (Panorama Screen) [1984]\Mickey Mouse (Nintendo, Panorama Screen).mgw
Game.Notes: Mickey Mouse is performing a baton trick in Donald's circus. The player must move left and right on the ball and catch all the batons as they fall, while dodging the ﬂaming torches. Mickey gets 1 point for every baton catch. If there are no misses when the player reach 300 points, the game goes into Chance Time and every baton is worth 2 points until a miss. Game B requires more coordination, technique and timing.
Game.Title: Mickey Mouse (Panorama Screen)

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Roller Coaster [1984]\Roller Coaster (VTech, Explorer Time & Fun).mgw
Game.Notes: Roller Coaster is a portable electronic game released by VTech under the Time & Fun brand in 1984. Apparently, this device was created in the likeness of the then popular series of portable electronic games Game & Watch from Nintendo.
Game.Title: Roller Coaster

Game.ApplicationPath: Games\Nintendo Game & Watch\Parachute [1981]\Parachute (Nintendo, Wide Screen).mgw
Game.Notes:
Parachute for the Game & Watch is game featuring skydivers parachuting over shark-infested waters. The player controls a lifeboat attempting to rescure the falling skydivers. The player must bove the lifeboat left and right to catch the skydivers. The player scores 1 point for every skydiver you successfully rescue. The number of skydivers increases (up to 10) as play progresses. When a skydiver falls into the water, he is attacked by sharks and you get a miss. If you get three misses then the game ends.
There are two game modes. In Game A, the task is to catch the falling skydivers. In Game B, the skydivers on the right side of the screen will occasionally get caught on a tree and swing there for a while before you can rescue them.
Game.Title: Parachute
